question_text: The most common congenital anomaly of the central nervous system is
explanation: Spina bifida is the most frequent CNS anomaly, caused by failure of neural tube closure. Anencephaly and hydrocephalus are also common but less frequent.
additional: High-yield: Prevention with folic acid supplementation before conception reduces risk of neural tube defects.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with absence of cranial vault is
explanation: Anencephaly results from failure of closure of the cranial end of neural tube, leading to absent cranial vault and cerebral hemispheres.
additional: High-yield: Incompatible with life; detectable on prenatal ultrasound.

question_text: The commonest congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract is
explanation: Imperforate anus is the most frequent congenital GI anomaly. Duodenal atresia and TEF are less common.
additional: High-yield: Present with absent anal opening and failure to pass meconium.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with 'double bubble sign' on X-ray is
explanation: The 'double bubble sign' is seen in duodenal atresia due to distension of the stomach and proximal duodenum.
additional: High-yield: Strongly associated with Down syndrome.

question_text: The congenital anomaly with failure of closure of anterior abdominal wall at umbilicus is
explanation: Omphalocele (exomphalos) is herniation of abdominal contents into a sac at the umbilicus. Gastroschisis lacks a covering sac.
additional: High-yield: Omphalocele is often associated with chromosomal anomalies.

question_text: The congenital anomaly with herniation of bowel through abdominal wall lateral to umbilicus without covering sac is
explanation: Gastroschisis is a paraumbilical defect where bowel herniates without peritoneal sac covering. Omphalocele has a sac.
additional: High-yield: Gastroschisis usually isolated, not syndromic.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with projectile non-bilious vomiting in a 3-week-old is
explanation: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting and visible peristalsis. Duodenal atresia causes bilious vomiting.
additional: High-yield: Classically first-born male, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

question_text: The congenital anomaly with failure of separation between trachea and oesophagus is
explanation: Tracheoesophageal fistula (commonly with oesophageal atresia) results from incomplete separation of trachea and oesophagus.
additional: High-yield: Present with frothing, choking, and aspiration pneumonia.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with absence of anal opening is
explanation: Imperforate anus is due to failure of development of anal canal opening. Hirschsprung’s is due to absent ganglion cells.
additional: High-yield: Always check perineum at birth.

question_text: The congenital anomaly where newborn presents with delayed meconium passage and abdominal distension is
explanation: Hirschsprung’s disease (congenital aganglionic megacolon) presents with delayed meconium and abdominal distension.
additional: High-yield: Associated with Down syndrome.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with meconium ileus is
explanation: Meconium ileus is pathognomonic of cystic fibrosis, presenting with intestinal obstruction at birth.
additional: High-yield: Thick, viscid meconium obstructs ileum.

question_text: Congenital talipes equinovarus is a deformity of
explanation: Congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) is a common congenital deformity of the foot.
additional: High-yield: Managed with Ponseti method (serial casting).

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with 'lemon sign' on ultrasound is
explanation: The 'lemon sign' (flattened frontal bones) is associated with spina bifida.
additional: High-yield: Often seen with Arnold–Chiari malformation.

question_text: The congenital anomaly that presents with continuous dribbling of urine in a girl child is
explanation: Bladder exstrophy presents with exposed bladder mucosa and continuous urine leakage.
additional: High-yield: Requires surgical repair.

question_text: The most common congenital anomaly of the genitourinary tract is
explanation: Hydronephrosis, often due to obstruction, is the most frequent congenital anomaly of the urinary tract.
additional: High-yield: Detected antenatally by ultrasound.

question_text: The congenital anomaly with failure of closure of vertebral arches without protrusion is
explanation: Spina bifida occulta is the mildest form, with vertebral defect but no protrusion of meninges or spinal cord.
additional: High-yield: May be seen as tuft of hair or dimple over spine.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with 'boot-shaped heart' on X-ray is
explanation: Tetralogy of Fallot produces a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette due to right ventricular hypertrophy.
additional: High-yield: Classic cyanotic congenital heart disease.

question_text: The congenital anomaly with cyanosis that worsens on crying but improves on squatting is
explanation: TOF presents with 'tet spells'—cyanosis worsens on exertion/crying and relieved by squatting due to increased systemic vascular resistance.
additional: High-yield: Squatting increases afterload, reducing right-to-left shunt.

question_text: The congenital anomaly where umbilical cord has only one artery is associated with
explanation: A single umbilical artery is strongly associated with renal anomalies and other genitourinary malformations.
additional: High-yield: Always evaluate kidneys by ultrasound if single umbilical artery is detected.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with 'machinery murmur' in neonates is
explanation: Patent ductus arteriosus produces a continuous 'machinery-like' murmur heard best at left infraclavicular area.
additional: High-yield: Common in preterm infants; may close with indomethacin or require surgery.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with cyanosis relieved by oxygen therapy is
explanation: Cyanosis that improves with oxygen indicates a pulmonary cause, not a cardiac one. Cardiac cyanotic defects do not improve with oxygen.
additional: High-yield: Oxygen challenge test differentiates cardiac vs pulmonary cyanosis.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with trisomy 21 is
explanation: Duodenal atresia is strongly associated with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).
additional: High-yield: 'Double bubble sign' on X-ray is classic finding.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with maternal oligohydramnios is
explanation: Bilateral renal agenesis causes oligohydramnios due to absent fetal urine production.
additional: High-yield: Leads to Potter sequence—facial anomalies, pulmonary hypoplasia, limb deformities.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with polyhydramnios is
explanation: Polyhydramnios is commonly due to oesophageal atresia because fetus cannot swallow amniotic fluid.
additional: High-yield: Other causes include anencephaly and maternal diabetes.

question_text: The congenital anomaly corrected by Ponseti method is
explanation: The Ponseti method uses gentle manipulation and serial casting to correct clubfoot.
additional: High-yield: Early initiation gives best outcomes.

question_text: The congenital anomaly with failure of closure of cranial bones and meninges protruding is
explanation: Encephalocele is a defect with herniation of brain tissue and meninges through cranial bone defect.
additional: High-yield: Often occipital in location.

question_text: The congenital anomaly associated with persistent ductus arteriosus is common in
explanation: Patent ductus arteriosus is more common in preterm babies due to immaturity of closure mechanisms.
additional: High-yield: Indomethacin/ibuprofen is used to induce closure.

question_text: The congenital anomaly where intestines herniate into umbilical cord covered by peritoneum is
explanation: Omphalocele (exomphalos) is herniation of abdominal contents into base of umbilical cord, covered by peritoneal sac.
additional: High-yield: Frequently associated with chromosomal abnormalities.
